Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content:
I can do `git diff branch-a branch-b` and see the changes, but I don't know how to commit some and not others.

Copy/pasting from within the terminal isn't good, because it adds a `+` or `-` for each line.

Author: Mylo#8306
Content:
I can‚Äôt say i have an efficient workflow for that, nor what PR etiquette is.
But doing something like
```
1.  git diff branch-a branch-b > mega.patch 
2.  sed -i ‚Äòs/^\-//g‚Äô mega.patch
3.  sed -i ‚Äòs/^\+//g‚Äô mega.patch
```
1.  Puts output to file `mega.patch`
2.  Replaces first char of each line (^) escaped (\) minus
3.  Same but with plus

That might give you something to work with.
In `mega.patch` you may be able to do some clever parsing to write smaller patches for individual files?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @Bryan_Beus `git add -p foo.cpp`

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: it spans many files

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `git add -p` lets you add `partial` parts of files

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: use `git add -p` many times, and you get to say "yes/no" to every changed chunk/hunk of text

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `git add -p foo1.cpp foo2.cpp`

Author: Bryan_Beus#6442
Content: do I need to indicate which branch to which branch?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `git add -p .`

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `git add -p` helps you build your next commit

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: instead of adding an entire file at a time, you can add changed parts of one/many files

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: what is the URL to the PR?

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: you can do this many times, and use `git add -p` to make many commits for you, if you wanted to say, split some of his changes into 3 commits

Content: just append .patch or .diff to a Github URL, and it will git you the thing

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content:
```NAME
       git-apply - Apply a patch to files and/or to the index

SYNOPSIS
       git apply [--stat] [--numstat] [--summary] [--check] [--index] [--3way]
                 [--apply] [--no-add] [--build-fake-ancestor=<file>] [-R | --reverse]
                 [--allow-binary-replacement | --binary] [--reject] [-z]
                 [-p<n>] [-C<n>] [--inaccurate-eof] [--recount] [--cached]
                 [--ignore-space-change | --ignore-whitespace ]
                 [--whitespace=(nowarn|warn|fix|error|error-all)]
                 [--exclude=<path>] [--include=<path>] [--directory=<root>]
                 [--verbose] [--unsafe-paths] [<patch>...]```

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: let's say you have 50 lines of changes, and actually, you want to commit it as 2 commits. That is the perfect use case

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: `git add -p` one part, commit, then the second

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: these parts can even be in the same file, which is like magic

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @blackjok3r make sure to enable `rerere`: https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Git-Tools-Rerere

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: basically, it makes Git remember merge conflicts that you resolved, and does the same thing in the future

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that one thing could drastically reduce your work, if there are many of the same changes you are dealing with, like a macro changing or a function signature changing over and over again

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's something nice, when you are dealing with conflicts no matter what
